history.content:
You can only retake if you fail, or get a NP.

=================================

Actually you can only retake if you received a grade of D+, D, D-, F, or NP, and D+/D/D- are not failing grades.

Source: https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades

You can only retake if you fail, or get a NP.

=================================

Actually you can only retake if you received a grade of D+, D, D-, F, or NP, and D+/D/D- are not failing grades.
You can only retake if you fail, or get a NP.

children.subject: I see. Any word on how dropping bellow 12 units would affect academic standing and financial aid eligibility?

Wait this is so unfair for people that have to P/NP. I personally feel pressure to take a grade too cuz of stuff like this...I feel kinda bad for the OP...What is it going to take for our school to just go with mandatory P/NP Smh...

In terms of how dropping below 12 units would affect standing/aid, I would contact Cal Student Central immediately to get an idea. I did this one semester in the past with no repercussions, but it can depend on the types of aid you receive.

Considering the special nature of this situation, you don't need to fail to retake the class. Rather than retaking it, you can just drop it in RRR week which would effectively perform the same function for the OP since it would allow them to do the class again and ensure a better grade.

history.content:
I need to do PNP, but I'm afraid that a P, instead of an A/A+, in core classes will hurt my chances when applying for the more competitive on campus researches with professors. You know ususally they require you to fill in a form of your grades in key classes for BAIR, for example. (As the 189 professor noted in an email this "might" be the case) Can I and should I retake a core upper div class to avoid being disatvantaged in research position applications? (not so familiar with the retake rule lol)

Obviously, I'm also considering retake because I don't think my work is solid enough this semester, but for this post I'm just focusing on the practical research getting problem.
history.subject: Retaking some important classes to get research
